header_summary:
Mark Erhardt and Antoine Riard engaged in a discussion, emphasizing the iterative nature of proposal development within the Bitcoin community, particularly concerning the amendment and refinement of proposals for Bitcoin Improvement. They considered the inclusion of a nomination process for Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) Editors but decided it would be more appropriate in a separate BIP, highlighting the importance of feedback and adjustments to maintain focus and clarity in proposals' objectives ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/CAMHHROw9mZJRnTbUo76PdqwJU==YJMvd9Qrst+nmyypaedYZgg@mail.gmail.com/T/#m82e3c7fa86ff8755b24bf69a9b43f432e0631363)).

Ava Chow announced the availability of the latest binaries for Bitcoin Core version v28.0rc2, marking a significant step towards the final release. This update, accessible for download and review, enters the release candidate stage, indicating intensive testing and final adjustments before the official launch. Contributors and users are encouraged to participate in this phase by testing the software and reviewing the preliminary release notes to ensure a smooth transition to the final version ([Bitcoin Core's official website](https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-28.0/test.rc2), [GitHub link](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/tree/v28.0rc2)).

Adam Gibson discussed the potential for double-spending within the Lightning Network's `channel_announcement` messages due to replay attacks. He proposed a solution leveraging the aut-ct construction and sigma-protocol type proofs to prevent such abuses, emphasizing the need for fast verification processes to avoid denial-of-service attacks. This conversation reflects ongoing efforts to enhance the security and efficiency of the Lightning Network through innovative cryptographic solutions ([source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/proving-utxo-set-inclusion-in-zero-knowledge/1142/10)).

Lastly, a theory diverging from the commonly held belief about Bitcoin's ossification process was presented by 1440000bytes. It suggests that the evolution and stabilization of Bitcoin are influenced by factors beyond algorithmic changes or market dynamics, including real-world power dynamics and strategies outlined in a document titled "Simple Sabotage." This perspective invites the community to consider broader socio-political forces at play in the cryptocurrency space, beyond technical and economic aspects ([Simple Sabotage](https://www.cia.gov/static/5c875f3ec660e092cf893f60b4a288df/SimpleSabotage.pdf)).

recent_posts.title: Adding New BIP Editors
recent_posts.summary:
- Mark Erhardt and Antoine Riard discussed improving a proposal's development.
- Suggested changes included clarifying mission statements and off-list correspondence handling.
- A separate BIP was proposed to nominate Bitcoin Improvement Proposal Editors.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 28.0 Release Candidate 2 Available
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version v28.0rc2 binaries are now available for download.
- The release marks the candidate stage for the major version, with draft notes outlining updates.
- If no significant issues, v28.0rc2 will officially become version 28.0, starting its deployment.

recent_posts.title: Public disclosure of 1 vulnerability affecting Bitcoin Core <24.0.1
recent_posts.summary:
- A new development in Bitcoin Core improves security without checkpoints.
- The update is part of an ongoing GitHub discussion focused on enhancing Bitcoin's functionality.
- Despite assumptions, checkpoints are currently used, marking an area for future improvement.

recent_posts.title: Proving UTXO set inclusion in zero-knowledge
recent_posts.summary:
- The email discusses double-spending risks in the Lightning Network through replay attacks.
- A solution using a "verifier’s public key" and sigma-protocol for secure channel announcements is proposed.
- It explores scalability and security enhancements via Curve Trees and STARK-based structures for the network.

recent_posts.title: Hybrid Jamming Mitigation: Results and Updates
recent_posts.summary:
- Nodes manage HTLCs by evaluating reputations and making informed decisions.
- A node's decision to forward an HTLC relies on reputational endorsements from connected nodes.
- This system of endorsements strengthens the network's defense against unsanctioned transactions.

recent_posts.title: Modeling (Social) Consensus About (Cryptographic) Consensus Change
recent_posts.summary:
- Alternative theory suggests Bitcoin's ossification influenced by more than halvings.
- Influential figures and financial stakeholders possibly steer Bitcoin's direction, challenging its decentralization.
- The discussion urges considering broader socio-political and economic factors in Bitcoin's evolution.

active_posts.title: Adding New BIP Editors
active_posts.summary:
- Friction in the Bitcoin Improvement Proposals process calls for more BIP editors.
- New BIP editors will inherit responsibilities like assigning BIP numbers and merging proposals.
- Kanzure and RubenSomsen are recommended as suitable candidates for BIP editors.

active_posts.title: Public disclosure of 1 vulnerability affecting Bitcoin Core <24.0.1
active_posts.summary:
- The Bitcoin Core team disclosed a new security vulnerability.
- A new disclosure policy on vulnerabilities is now in effect.
- Further updates on past vulnerabilities will be released next month.

active_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 28.0 Release Candidate 2 Available
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version v28.0rc2 binaries are now available for download.
- This update is a step towards the official release of a new major version.
- Release candidate v28.0rc2 is crucial for final testing before the version 28.0 launch.

active_posts.title: PPLNS with job declaration
active_posts.summary:
- An SV2 extension is being developed to increase mining pool payout transparency and fairness.
- Miners will gain more control by selecting transactions, affecting fees and job choices.
- The project seeks contributions for refinement, building on the PPLNS system and detailed on GitHub.

active_posts.title: Who will run the CoinJoin coordinators?
active_posts.summary:
- Recent crackdowns have altered the Bitcoin privacy service landscape, closing key platforms.
- Alternatives like JoinMarket and the BTCPay Server CoinJoin plugin are gaining traction.
- The community's adaptation may lead to a resilient decentralized network or innovative privacy solutions.

active_posts.title: SuperScalar: Laddered Timeout-Tree-Structured Decker-Wattenhofer Factories
active_posts.summary:
- The SuperScalar mechanism enhances Bitcoin Lightning Network liquidity without blockchain changes.
- It uses Decker-Wattenhofer mechanisms, timeout trees, and laddering for secure, scalable transactions.
- Practical considerations include incentivizing user activity and optimizing tree structures for efficiency.

today_in_history_posts.title: Year 2038 problem and year 2106 chain halting
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core might stop working in 2038 due to a time checking issue.
- The entire chain will halt in 2106 after reaching a specific median time.
- There is uncertainty about resolving these issues with a soft-fork solution.

today_in_history_posts.title: Stateless invoices with proof-of-payment
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Lightning invoices can now be generated statelessly, eliminating the need for storage.
- Stateless invoices pose identification and preimage retrieval issues upon payment reception.
- Solutions include adding custom tlv records or using deterministic preimages for problem resolution.

today_in_history_posts.title: Covenant tools softfork
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The proposed softfork introduces consensus changes to enhance Bitcoin security and efficiency.
- BIP-118, BIP-119, and BIP-345 have been scrutinized and demonstrate stable enhancements, particularly for Bitcoin vaults.
- The implementation involves 7,000 lines of code, suggesting manageable review and deployment efforts for BIP-345.
